text: [Music]
my personal process is one of of
maintaining a very
uh I would say monastic discipline I
mean I essentially do the same thing
every day seven days a week and I've
done that for years besides from the
things I have to do besides from
socializing which I like to do
occasionally uh besides from traveling
which I like to do less now that I'm
older and that you have to take off your
shoes uh I basically go to my studio
and you know as trivial as it might seem
to somebody
else there's always
something there's always a little
problem that needs to be figured out so
I feel like my studio uh is a laboratory
you know and you know there is a sense
of alchemy there is a sense of chemistry
there is a sense of Joy there is a sense
of the pleasure that I have in playing
with this stuff paint the stuff you know
that I
basically
understand on some
level you could garnish it with all
kinds of of theoretical constructs but
it's it's a person alone in a
room making things with their
hands and I like to keep it that simple
a lot of days and when you're making
things and when you have your little
cottage
industry there's always something to do
when I go to my studio I start out by
sweeping the
floor I start out by making sure
everything's in order I start out by
trying to make sure my mind is
clear and then I think about the problem
that didn't get solved
yesterday and that opens it up for
me so I think that's the
process what's the problem today is the
question I ask
myself
um there always seems to be
something I'm most
happy
uh
when
I I'm not distracted when I'm working
when I could go to my studio when I
somehow could live in that presence that
presence and the
present and I could do it
repetitively so
that you kind of build up a steam you
know it's like a it's like an engine
it's like a it's like a
percolator
and sometimes it just
becomes you
know it really
becomes a kind of a concentration that's
so pure
that I think is both playful and
imaginative and opens up all kinds of
new possibilities for me
